questions.text: Among the given options, murmur given in the image is associated with? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Mitral Regurgitation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mitral regurgitation is associated with a pan-systolic murmur, which is present throughout the systole and heard between the S1 and S2 heart sounds.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female with a history of chest pain and upper respiratory tract infection, seven days ago, presents with shortness of breath. She has BP of 100/60 mm Hg and a pulse rate of 110/min. Chest x-ray reviews an enlarged heart, which appears like a water bottle. Which of the following is incorrect? (INICET MAY 2024)

options.label: C
options.text: Loud S1 is a common finding

options.label: D
options.text: Echo will show diastolic RA/RV collapse

questions.correct_answer: C. Loud S1 is a common finding
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cardiac tamponade, muffled heart sounds are a key finding, not a loud S1.

questions.text: Below is a radioactive scan for thyroid pathology. which of the following is the most probable diagnosis: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hypersecreting Adenoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypersecreting adenoma in the thyroid is characterized by increased radioactive uptake in one area of the thyroid with suppression in other areas, reflecting independent hormone production from the adenoma.

questions.text: A patient with retro-positive status was started on 2nd line highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART). Which of the following can be used to monitor treatment efficacy? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Viral load measurement is the most important and recommended method for monitoring the efficacy of antiretroviral therapy in HIV patients. The goal is to achieve an undetectable viral load (<50 copies/mL).

questions.text: Order in which the following heart sounds are heard from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall? (INICET MAY 2023) 1.Pulmonary area 2.Erb’s area 3.Mitral area
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 → 2 → 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct order from superior to inferior for heart sounds on the left side chest wall is pulmonary area, Erb’s area, and mitral area.

questions.text: Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is due to which of the following? (AIIMS MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Asthenospermia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Infertility in Kartagener's syndrome is primarily due to asthenospermia, which is caused by the immobility of sperm. This immotility results from the genetic defect affecting the dynein arm of sperm flagella, similar to the defect affecting cilia in the respiratory tract, leading to the classic symptoms of the syndrome.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Pulmonology/Bronchiectasis/Chapter 290

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with an acute onset of chest pain radiating to the left arm and diaphoresis. His ECG and cardiac biomarkers show non-ST elevation myocardial infarction. Which of the following will be used in the treatment of this patient? ( INICET Nov 2023) 1. Atorvastatin 2. Aspirin 3. Clopidogrel 4. Low molecular weight heparin 5. Alteplase
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2, 3, 4

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the management of non-ST elevation myocardial infarction (NSTEMI), several medications are routinely used to reduce the risk of further ischemic events and manage the condition effectively:
  • • Atorvastatin: High-intensity statin therapy is recommended to lower cholesterol levels and stabilize atherosclerotic plaques. Aspirin: This antiplatelet agent is essential for reducing clot formation and preventing further arterial blockage. Clopidogrel: Another antiplatelet agent, often used in combination with aspirin, to provide dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), which is beneficial in preventing further ischemic events. Low molecular weight heparin: Anticoagulant therapy, such as enoxaparin, is crucial in preventing thrombus formation and managing NSTEMI. Enoxaparin is typically administered subcutaneously at a dose of 1 mg/kg twice daily.
  • • Atorvastatin: High-intensity statin therapy is recommended to lower cholesterol levels and stabilize atherosclerotic plaques.
  • • Aspirin: This antiplatelet agent is essential for reducing clot formation and preventing further arterial blockage.
  • • Clopidogrel: Another antiplatelet agent, often used in combination with aspirin, to provide dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT), which is beneficial in preventing further ischemic events.
  • • Low molecular weight heparin: Anticoagulant therapy, such as enoxaparin, is crucial in preventing thrombus formation and managing NSTEMI. Enoxaparin is typically administered subcutaneously at a dose of 1 mg/kg twice daily.
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • 5. Alteplase: This thrombolytic agent is used in the management of ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI) when percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) is not immediately available. It is not indicated for NSTEMI due to the lack of ST elevation and the associated risks of bleeding without significant benefit.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For NSTEMI management, the treatment includes Atorvastatin, Aspirin, Clopidogrel, and Low molecular weight heparin. Thrombolytic agents like Alteplase are reserved for STEMI with specific indications.

questions.text: Following is a graphic representation of a patient admitted in medicine ward with fever. What could be the possible diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a biphasic fever pattern, especially when supported by epidemiologic data pointing to possible exposure to contaminated water or animals. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as Weil's disease, which can lead to severe renal and hepatic issues.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21/Leptospirosis/Chap 184

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman with no significant past medical history presents to the emergency department with a complaint of severe headaches. Physical examination reveals a slightly elevated blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg, and the neurological exam shows no focal deficits, but the patient appears visibly distressed and in pain. Which of the following types of headaches requires further evaluation? Headache lasting more than a few hours without relief Sudden onset severe headache described as the "worst headache of life" New-onset headache that is progressively worsening Headache associated with visual symptoms, such as blurred vision
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option 2: Sudden onset severe headache described as the "worst headache of life" This description is a classic red flag for a subarachnoid hemorrhage, particularly when the headache occurs suddenly and with severe intensity. Such a presentation requires immediate evaluation with neuroimaging, typically a CT scan, to rule out a potentially life-threatening condition.
  • • Option 2: Sudden onset severe headache described as the "worst headache of life"
  • • Option 3: New-onset headache that is progressively worsening A new, progressively worsening headache, particularly in a patient without a prior history of similar headaches, suggests a serious underlying condition such as a brain tumor, increased intracranial pressure, or another significant pathology. This warrants further evaluation with neuroimaging to determine the cause.
  • • Option 3: New-onset headache that is progressively worsening
  • • Option 4: Headache associated with visual symptoms, such as blurred vision Headaches with associated visual symptoms raise concern for conditions like increased intracranial pressure, optic neuritis, or other neurological disorders. Blurred vision with headache necessitates prompt evaluation to exclude serious conditions.
  • • Option 4: Headache associated with visual symptoms, such as blurred vision
  • • Other Option:
  • • Other Option:
  • • Option 1: Headache lasting more than a few hours without relief While prolonged headaches can be distressing, they often occur in benign conditions such as migraines or tension-type headaches. The duration alone does not necessitate urgent evaluation unless it is accompanied by other red flag symptoms, such as neurological changes or sudden onset.
  • • Option 1: Headache lasting more than a few hours without relief

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Headaches that present as the worst headache of one’s life, are new and progressively worsening, or are associated with visual disturbances require urgent medical evaluation. These red flags suggest potential serious conditions like subarachnoid hemorrhage, brain tumors, or increased intracranial pressure, necessitating prompt investigation and management to prevent complications.

questions.text: All of the following are AIDS defining illnesses except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Oral Candidiasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Infectious Disease/Chap 202

questions.text: A 40-year-old chronic alcoholic presented with withdrawal symptoms. His liver function tests showed: AST 140 IU/L, ALT 110 IU/L, and GGT 500 IU/L. Which of the following benzodiazepines can be safely administered to this patient? ( INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with liver impairment, such as those with alcoholic hepatitis, lorazepam is the preferred benzodiazepine due to its short-acting nature and minimal hepatic metabolism.

questions.text: A morbidly obese diabetic woman is not responsive to metformin therapy. She has a history of pancreatitis and family history of bladder cancer. She does not want to take injections. Which of the following would be suitable to reduce her glucose levels? (AIIMS NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Canagliflozin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In choosing diabetes medications for patients with specific health concerns, it's crucial to consider both the efficacy and the side-effect profile of the drug, as well as patient preferences for administration methods to ensure compliance and safety. Canagliflozin is an appropriate choice for this patient due to its oral administration and lower risk concerning her medical history.

questions.text: A patient presented with violent, flinging movements. Where is the lesion causing the hemiballismus seen? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Subthalamic nucleus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemiballismus, characterized by violent, flinging movements, is most commonly caused by a lesion in the subthalamic nucleus.

questions.text: A 53-year-old gentleman presents with chest pain which is happening at rest. Pain is persistent for 3-5 minutes and he is having recurrent pain over the last 48 hours and he used 3 puffs of GTN to relieve his pain. His current medications include GTN PRN, Atorvastatin 20mg HS, Metoprolol 50mg BID, and Aspirin 75mg OD. His troponin was negative and ECG showed LVH with flattening of the ST segment. What is the most appropriate next step in management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Start enoxaparin 1mg/kg s.c BD

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In patients with high-risk unstable angina, especially those with recurrent chest pain at rest and ECG changes, initiating therapeutic anticoagulation with enoxaparin is a critical step in the acute management to prevent thrombus formation and progression to myocardial infarction.

questions.text: Which of the following pairings of seizure type and anti-epileptic drug (AED) is incorrect? (AIIMS NOV 2016)

options.label: A
options.text: Focal seizures: Lamotrigine, Carbamazepine, Phenytoin, Valproate

options.label: D
options.text: Generalized tonic clonic seizures: Valproate, Lamotrigine, Topiramate, Phenytoin, Carbamazepine

questions.correct_answer: B. Absence seizure: Carbamazepine Ethosuximide, Valproate
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The incorrect pairing is Absence Seizures: Carbamazepine, Ethosuximide, Valproate. Carbamazepine is not used in the treatment of absence seizures; in fact, it can exacerbate them. Ethosuximide and Valproate are the appropriate first-line treatment options for absence seizures.
  • • Selection of Anti-Epileptic Drugs
  • • Selection of Anti-Epileptic Drugs
  • • Alternatives
  • • Drug of Choice for Various Types of Seizures
  • • Drug of Choice for Various Types of Seizures
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Focal Seizures : Lamotrigine, Carbamazepine, Phenytoin, Valproate: This is a correct pairing, as all these drugs are used in the treatment of focal seizures.
  • • Option A. Focal Seizures
  • • Option C. Myoclonic Seizures : Valproate, Lamotrigine, Clonazepam: This is also a correct pairing, as these drugs are used to manage myoclonic seizures.
  • • Option C. Myoclonic Seizures
  • • Option D. Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures : Valproate, Lamotrigine, Topiramate, Phenytoin, Carbamazepine: This pairing is accurate as well, with all listed drugs being used to treat generalized tonic-clonic seizures.
  • • Option D. Generalized Tonic-Clonic Seizures

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carbamazepine is contraindicated in absence seizures and can worsen them. Ethosuximide and Valproate are the preferred first-line treatments for absence seizures.

questions.text: Identify the pathology from the given flow-volume loop: (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Fixed central airway obstruction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Flattening of both inspiratory and expiratory limbs in a flow-volume loop indicates a fixed central airway obstruction.

questions.text: All of the following are the core clinical features for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Orthostatic hypotension.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Orthostatic hypotension is a supportive, not core, criterion for the diagnosis of Lewy body dementia.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison 21e/Neurology, DLB Chapter 434 /12305.

questions.text: A patient came with hypoxemia and a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. What can be the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hypoventilation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypoventilation is a primary cause of hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient.

questions.text: What is the most common presentation of inhalational anthrax? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hemorrhagic mediastinitis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hemorrhagic mediastinitis is the hallmark presentation of inhalational anthrax, indicating a severe systemic infection that requires immediate medical attention and aggressive antibiotic therapy. Awareness of this presentation is crucial, particularly in contexts involving potential exposure to anthrax spores, such as bioterrorism.

questions.text: A patient presented with the complaints of chest pain. Which among the following is the best investigation to diagnose MI within 2-4 hours? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Troponin – T

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rise by >20%of troponin is used for diagnosis of Reinfarction
  • ➤ Newer biomarkers: HFABP, miRNA1,21,33

References:

  • ↳ Reference - (Cardiology/Biomarkers, MI)

questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Child-Turcotte-Pugh scoring system

  • ➤ Inference:

  • ➤ CTP A: 5-6
  • ➤ CTP A:
  • ➤ CTP B: 7-9
  • ➤ CTP B:
  • ➤ CTP C: 10-15
  • ➤ CTP C:

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Cirrhosis/Chapter 344

questions.text: The blood investigation of a patient is given below. What is the probable diagnosis? ( INICET Nov 2023) HBsAg - NR, Anti HBs - NR, Anti HBc IgM - NR, Anti HBc total - positive, HBeAg - NR, Anti HBe – NR (NR – Non reactive)

options.label: A
options.text: Acute HBV infection in window period

options.label: C
options.text: HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

questions.correct_answer: C. HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) HBV infection in the remote past, completely recovered

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient's serological markers indicate the following:
  • • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.
  • • HBsAg - Non-Reactive (NR): This suggests that the patient is not currently infected with Hepatitis B.
  • • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.
  • • Anti HBs - NR: Lack of antibodies against the Hepatitis B surface antigen suggests no current immunity from vaccination or recent infection.
  • • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection. Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.
  • • Anti HBc IgM - NR: The absence of IgM antibodies against the core antigen indicates no recent acute infection.
  • • Anti HBc total - positive: Presence of total core antibodies (including IgG) indicates past exposure to the virus.
  • • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.
  • • HBeAg - NR: Absence of the e antigen suggests no active viral replication.
  • • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.
  • • Anti HBe - NR: Absence of antibodies against the e antigen suggests no current or recent active infection.
  • • Given these markers, the most likely scenario is that the patient had a Hepatitis B infection in the past and has completely recovered. The presence of Anti HBc total (which is predominantly IgG) signifies past infection. In cases of remote past infection, anti-HBs antibodies may fall below detectable levels, although the patient still has immunity through memory B cells.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period: In the window period of acute HBV infection, Anti HBc IgM should be positive, which is not the case here.
  • • Option A. Acute HBV infection in window period:
  • • Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine: Patients vaccinated against HBV typically have positive Anti HBs and negative Anti HBc total, as they have not been exposed to the virus.
  • • Option B. Immune with recombinant HBV Vaccine:
  • • Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier: Chronic HBV infection requires the presence of HBsAg for more than six months. The absence of HBsAg rules out chronic infection.
  • • Option D. Chronic HBV infection inactive carrier:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The presence of Anti HBc total (predominantly IgG) with all other markers negative suggests a past HBV infection that has completely resolved.

questions.text: Which of the following is seen in MEN 2B syndrome? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Medullary thyroid carcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The most significant feature of MEN 2B syndrome is the presence of medullary thyroid carcinoma, alongside mucosal neuromas and a marfanoid body habitus, often linked to mutations in the RET proto-oncogene

questions.text: A patient with glaucoma presents with a bulging cornea. What is the most likely diagnosis? ( AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Staphyloma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Staphyloma, particularly anterior and ciliary types, can develop due to high intraocular pressure in glaucoma, leading to the protrusion of the uveal tissue through a weakened cornea or sclera.

questions.text: A 62-year-old man with a history of hypertension and smoking presents to the emergency department with sudden onset of dizziness, difficulty swallowing, and slurred speech. He reports numbness on the right side of his face and left side of his body, along with blurred vision and a hoarse voice. On examination, he has right-sided Horner's syndrome (ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis), right-sided facial numbness, dysphagia, hoarseness, and diminished gag reflex. His left arm and leg have impaired pain and temperature sensation. Which of the following arteries is most likely affected?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient’s symptoms are consistent with lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome), commonly due to thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA). This condition involves multiple structures on the side of the lesion, including the vestibular nuclei (leading to vertigo and nausea), descending sympathetic tract (resulting in Horner’s syndrome), trigeminal nerve nucleus (causing facial numbness), and cranial nerves IX and X (causing dysphagia and hoarseness). Additionally, contralateral spinothalamic tract involvement results in impaired pain and temperature sensation on the opposite side of the body.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Basilar artery A basilar artery stroke often affects the pons and midbrain, leading to severe symptoms such as locked-in syndrome, cranial nerve abnormalities, and quadriplegia, which do not match this patient’s presentation.
  • • Option A. Basilar artery
  • • Option B. Vertebral artery Vertebral artery strokes can cause a wide variety of brainstem and cerebellar symptoms, but they often present with more diffuse findings compared to PICA strokes. They can sometimes contribute to PICA infarction, but specific involvement of lateral medullary structures like those described here is most characteristic of isolated PICA occlusion.
  • • Option B. Vertebral artery
  • • Option D. Middle cerebral artery (MCA) MCA strokes typically involve the cerebral cortex, presenting with contralateral motor and sensory deficits, aphasia (if the dominant hemisphere is involved), and neglect (if the non-dominant hemisphere is affected). They do not cause the brainstem symptoms described in this case.
  • • Option D. Middle cerebral artery (MCA)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) results from thrombosis of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) and presents with a distinctive pattern of cranial nerve deficits, ipsilateral Horner’s syndrome, and contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation. Understanding the unique symptomatology of brainstem stroke syndromes aids in prompt recognition and management.

questions.text: A pregnant woman has a fetus with Down's syndrome. Triple test done at 15-16 weeks will have? (INICET NOV 2017)

options.label: A
options.text: Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3

options.label: B
options.text: High MSAFP, low hCG, high UE3

options.label: C
options.text: Low MSAFP, high hCG, high UE3

options.label: D
options.text: High MSAFP, low hCG, low UE3

questions.correct_answer: A. Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Low MSAFP, high hCG, low UE3

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The triple and quadruple test is done between 15 – 21 weeks.
  • • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.
  • • Components of Triple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3) and Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein.
  • • Components of the Quadruple test are: Free β hCG, unconjugated Estriol (uE3), Maternal Serum α-fetoprotein. And Inhibin A.
  • • *Easy to remember: B for B ig; so in Down’s syndrome; B eta hCG and Inhi B in A: B ig/ Increased
  • • B
  • • B
  • • B
  • • B
  • • B

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The triple test results for Down's syndrome typically show low MSAFP, high hCG, and low uE3.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 859, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 859, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: The most appropriate expansion of Apgar is: (AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.correct_answer: C. Appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, respiration
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Appearance, pulse, grimace, activity, respiration

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Apgar score assesses a newborn's health based on five criteria: Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, and Respiration.

questions.text: A baby presented with abdominal pain. On examination, a mass is palpated in the right lumbar region. A barium enema is done, and the image is given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Intussusception

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Intussusception presents with cramping abdominal pain, palpable mass, and red currant jelly stools, and is confirmed by imaging showing the claw sign.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents in OPD with complaints of cyclical pain in abdomen. On examination, a suprapubic bulge can be seen in the pelvic area. PR examination reveals a swelling in the anterior aspect. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Transverse vaginal septum above the vagina

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given case scenario points to a diagnosis of cryptomenorrhea, due to an imperforate hymen.
  • • Cryptomenorrhea is a condition in which menstruation occurs but is not visible due to obstruction of the outflow tract resulting in either hematometra (blood collection within the uterus) or hematocolpos (blood collection within vagina). In the long term, it may result in endometriosis, urinary retention and infertility.
  • • IMPERFORATE HYMEN
  • • IMPERFORATE HYMEN
  • • Presents as cryptomenorrhea H/o cyclical abdominal pain/cyclical dysmenorrhea Local examination: bluish bulge with intact hymen On P/R: swelling (hematocolpos) felt along length of vagina anteriorly Treatment: Cruciate incision.
  • • Presents as cryptomenorrhea
  • • H/o cyclical abdominal pain/cyclical dysmenorrhea
  • • Local examination: bluish bulge with intact hymen
  • • On P/R: swelling (hematocolpos) felt along length of vagina anteriorly
  • • Treatment: Cruciate incision.
  • • In Imperforate hymen, swelling is seen all along the length of the vagina on PR examination as there is hematocolpos (blood in the vagina)
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Transverse vaginal septum : Transverse vaginal septum is a Müllerian anomaly. On examination, blind vagina is found. No tense blue hymen and cough impulse will be absent. Diagnosis can be confirmed by MRI
  • • Option A. Transverse vaginal septum
  • • Option B. Vaginal atresia : If vaginal introitus is not seen, then it’s vaginal atresia
  • • Option B. Vaginal atresia
  • • Option D. Cervical agenesis : Cervical agenesis will show absence of a cervix is on examination.
  • • Option D. Cervical agenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Imperforate hymen presents with cryptomenorrhea, characterized by cyclical abdominal pain and hematocolpos due to obstruction of menstrual flow, with a suprapubic bulge and anterior swelling palpable on PR examination.

questions.text: In the 18th century, the East India Company engaged in the illicit trade of a specific substance with China, which played a significant role in the historical trade dynamics. What was the substance that the company smuggled into China during this time? ( INICET Nov 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Opium

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In 18 th & 19 th centuaries, EIC (East India Company) used to purchase Tea against Silver. By opium export, EIC were able to save their Silver and purchased tea against Opium.
  • • Opium is derived from the poppy plant and has been used both medicinally and recreationally.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Cannabis: Marijuana, a psychoactive drug from the Cannabis plant, used both recreationally and medicinally around the world.
  • • Option B. Cannabis: Marijuana, a
  • • Option C. Magic Mushrooms : Refer to various types of mushrooms that contain psilocybin, a psychoactive compound. These have been used for centuries for their hallucinogenic effects.
  • • Option C. Magic Mushrooms
  • • Option D. Cocaine : Derived from the coca plant, cocaine is a powerful stimulant used primarily as a recreational drug.
  • • Option D. Cocaine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ In 18 th century British East India company used to transport opium to China .

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presented with developmental delay, recurrent chest infections and worsening bony pain. His serum PTH was normal. Calcium was normal and phosphate was low. There is no response to Vitamin D. The probable diagnosis is:(NEET PG 2021)

options.label: C
options.text: Vitamin D dependent rickets type I

options.label: D
options.text: Vitamin D dependent rickets type II

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ X-linked hypophosphatemic rickets is a genetic disorder that results in low phosphate levels and can present with bony pain, developmental delay, and recurrent infections. It is distinct from other forms of rickets due to its genetic basis and the characteristic low phosphate levels in the absence of Vitamin D response.
  • ➤ Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562285/
  • ➤ Ref - https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562285/

questions.text: Which of the following antiarrhythmic drugs is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Amiodarone

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Amiodarone is contraindicated in patients with interstitial lung disease due to its potential to cause pulmonary fibrosis, a serious and potentially irreversible adverse effect. It is essential to consider this risk when prescribing antiarrhythmic therapy to patients with pre-existing lung conditions.

questions.text: A 72-year-old male with a history of high blood pressure and recent mood fluctuations presents with persistent difficulty passing stool. His blood pressure is elevated while sitting but drops significantly when lying down. He is currently taking amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, sertraline, olanzapine, and psyllium husk. Which of the following interventions is most appropriate? (AIIMS NOV 2016)

options.label: A
options.text: Replace amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide with losartan and a different diuretic, and add polyethylene glycol for constipation.

options.label: B
options.text: Discontinue sertraline and olanzapine, start a new antidepressant and antipsychotic, and add polyethylene glycol.

options.label: C
options.text: Continue current medications and add senna for constipation relief.

options.label: D
options.text: Stop all medications and initiate corticosteroid therapy.

questions.correct_answer: A. Replace amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide with losartan and a different diuretic, and add polyethylene glycol for constipation.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The patient is experiencing orthostatic hypotension, indicated by the significant drop in blood pressure when changing from sitting to lying down. This could be a side effect of his antihypertensive medications (amlodipine and hydrochlorothiazide). Additionally, constipation could be exacerbated by these medications or the antipsychotic olanzapine.
  • • The best approach is to address both issues simultaneously. Switching to an angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB) like losartan can help manage hypertension while minimizing the risk of orthostatic hypotension. Changing to a different diuretic can further mitigate the risk of low blood pressure upon standing. Adding polyethylene glycol, an osmotic laxative, can effectively relieve constipation without interacting with other medications.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B: Changing psychotropic medications might not be the primary concern, as the orthostatic hypotension and constipation may be primarily medication-related.
  • • Option B:
  • • Option C: Adding senna without addressing the medications causing orthostatic hypotension might not be the most effective approach.
  • • Option C:
  • • Option D: Stopping all medications abruptly and starting steroids is not recommended as it can lead to withdrawal symptoms and other complications.
  • • Option D:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In elderly patients with orthostatic hypotension and constipation, consider adjusting medications that may contribute to these issues. Look for alternative antihypertensives and constipation relief options that have a lower risk of side effects and drug interactions

questions.text: Select the correct sequence: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenylyl cyclase → cAMP → PKA

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The sequence involves the activation of a G protein-coupled receptor pathway. When a hormone binds to its receptor, the associated heterotrimeric G protein undergoes a conformational change. This change leads to the exchange of GDP for GTP on the G protein's alpha subunit, causing it to dissociate from the beta and gamma subunits.
  • • The activated GTP-bound alpha subunit then interacts with adenylyl cyclase, an enzyme located on the inner membrane of the cell. Adenylyl cyclase converts ATP into cyclic AMP (cAMP). The newly formed cAMP acts as a secondary messenger that activates Protein Kinase A (PKA). PKA, in turn, phosphorylates various target proteins, leading to a cascade of cellular responses.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct sequence in the G protein-coupled receptor pathway is: Adenylyl cyclase activates the conversion of ATP to cAMP, which then activates Protein Kinase A (PKA).

questions.text: The image below shows a pressure sore. Which stage does this belong to?(NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation: Ans. D) Stage 4

questions.text: A woman who had undergone total knee replacement surgery comes with complaints of knee pain with the loosening of implants. The following histopathological slide was obtained which showed foreign body giant cells along with the appearance highlighted in the image below. What is your diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metallosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metallosis is a rare complication of joint replacement surgeries, characterized by the release of metallic debris from implants, leading to a foreign body reaction with the formation of foreign body giant cells and potential loosening of the implant.

questions.text: What is correct regarding the diagnosis based on the given image? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: A

options.label: B

questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Herpes zoster , commonly involves reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus within the dorsal root ganglion , leading to painful cutaneous eruptions that can affect mucous membranes within the involved dermatomes . Herpes zoster lesions are infectious , particularly to those who are not immune to varicella-zoster virus , and thoracic dermatome is the most frequently affected area.
  • ➤ Herpes zoster , commonly involves reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus within the dorsal root ganglion , leading to painful cutaneous eruptions that can affect mucous membranes within the involved dermatomes .
  • ➤ Herpes zoster

  • ➤ mucous membranes
  • ➤ dermatomes
  • ➤ Herpes zoster lesions are infectious , particularly to those who are not immune to varicella-zoster virus , and thoracic dermatome is the most frequently affected area.

questions.text: Bone marrow aspirate of a patient shows the following features. Which of the following is true? ( INICET NOV 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite

options.label: B
options.text: It is an obligate extracellular parasite

options.label: D
options.text: Stibogluconate is the first line of treatment in India

questions.correct_answer: A. Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Buffy coat is used to diagnose the parasite

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Buffy coat is used to diagnose Leishmania donovani by detecting the amastigote form in intracellular macrophages in patients with visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Arrange the structures of the cubital fossa in sequence from medial to lateral? ( INICET Nov 2022) 1. Median nerve 2. Radial nerve 3. Tendon of biceps brachi 4. Brachial artery
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. 1,4,3,2

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The structures are arranged in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral as follows:
  • • 1. Median nerve
  • • 2. Brachial artery
  • • 3. Tendon of biceps brachii
  • • 4. Radial nerve
  • • The cubital fossa is actually a triangular area located on the anterior aspect of the elbow, not the upper forearm. It is bounded by several structures, including:
  • • The lateral border of the pronator teres muscle, which forms the medial boundary The medial border of the brachioradialis muscle, which forms the lateral boundary The imaginary line connecting the epicondyles of the humerus, which forms the superior boundary The floor of the cubital fossa is formed by the brachialis and supinator muscles, while the roof is formed by the Deep fascia of the skin.
  • • The lateral border of the pronator teres muscle, which forms the medial boundary
  • • The medial border of the brachioradialis muscle, which forms the lateral boundary
  • • The imaginary line connecting the epicondyles of the humerus, which forms the superior boundary
  • • The floor of the cubital fossa is formed by the brachialis and supinator muscles, while the roof is formed by the Deep fascia of the skin.
  • • The cubital fossa contains several important structures, including the brachial artery, radial nerve, and median nerve. It is a common site for blood draws and intravenous catheter placement due to the relatively superficial location of the structures and ease of access.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The correct anatomical sequencing of structures in the cubital fossa from medial to lateral—median nerve, brachial artery, tendon of biceps brachii, and radial nerve—is essential for both anatomical education and practical clinical applications.

questions.text: A 26-year-old male presents with back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes. X-ray of the patient is given below. Identify the diagnosis of this patient: (NEET PG 2021)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The described symptoms of back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes, along with the bamboo spine appearance in the spine x-ray are diagnostic of ankylosing spondylitis.
  • ➤ The described symptoms of back ache, morning stiffness and reddening of eyes, along with the bamboo spine appearance in the spine x-ray are diagnostic of ankylosing spondylitis.

questions.text: A skull was recovered from a forest. According to inquest papers, woman had gone missing after a fight with her boyfriend a month back. The skull was sent to the forensic research lab. Which of the following would identify it as a female skull? ( INICET May 2021) Large frontal and parietal eminence Heavy cheek bones Smooth glabella Square orbits Narrow mastoid
questions.explanation: Ans.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found unresponsive at the scene of a severe car accident. She is intubated on arrival due to poor airway protection and decreased consciousness. On examination, she opens her eyes only to painful stimuli and exhibits abnormal flexion in response to pain. Her pupils are reactive to light. The trauma team assesses her Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score to monitor her neurological status. Based on her clinical findings, which of the following is her most appropriate GCS score?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) score evaluates eye, verbal, and motor responses to determine the level of consciousness in patients with traumatic brain injury (TBI). In this scenario, the patient scores 2 for eye opening to pain (E2), non-testable (NT) for verbal due to intubation, and 3 for abnormal flexion (M3). Thus, the GCS score is recorded as E2VNTM3. Non-testability (NT) denotes the inability to assess the verbal component due to intubation, often seen in acute TBI cases. The GCS-P score further refines this evaluation by considering pupillary activity, enhancing prognostic accuracy. While this patient’s GCS score focuses on eye and motor responses, her reactive pupils indicate no additional pupillary penalty in the GCS-P calculation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. E1VNTM2: This score implies no eye opening and abnormal extension (M2), which does not match the observed painful eye opening (E2) and abnormal flexion (M3).
  • • Option A. E1VNTM2:
  • • Option B. E3VNTM2: This score incorrectly suggests eye opening to verbal command and abnormal extension posturing, which does not align with the patient's eye response to pain and abnormal flexion motor response.
  • • Option B. E3VNTM2:
  • • Option C. E2VNTM4: This option overestimates the motor response as withdrawal from pain (M4), which inaccurately reflects the patient’s actual abnormal flexion.
  • • Option C. E2VNTM4:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS) is a widely used tool for assessing the level of consciousness in traumatic brain injury. Intubated patients are marked as non-testable (NT) for verbal response, focusing on eye and motor components. The GCS-P score further refines the assessment by incorporating pupillary activity, enhancing sensitivity and specificity in acute brain injury evaluation.

questions.text: The best way to manage the wound shown in the image is: (AIIMS MAY 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cleaning and dressing

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Here are some general principles for the management of a superficial abrasion:
  • ➤ Clean the wound: Gently clean the wound with soap and warm water to remove any dirt or debris. Use a clean cloth or sterile gauze to pat the wound dry. Apply a dressing: Cover the abrasion with a sterile dressing or adhesive bandage to keep it clean and protected. Change the dressing daily or more often if it becomes wet or dirty. Manage pain: Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help relieve pain and reduce inflammation. Watch for signs of infection: Keep an eye on the abrasion for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, pus, or increasing pain. Follow up: Depending on the severity of the abrasion, you may need to follow up with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and treatment.
  • ➤ Clean the wound: Gently clean the wound with soap and warm water to remove any dirt or debris. Use a clean cloth or sterile gauze to pat the wound dry.
  • ➤ Apply a dressing: Cover the abrasion with a sterile dressing or adhesive bandage to keep it clean and protected. Change the dressing daily or more often if it becomes wet or dirty.
  • ➤ Manage pain: Over-the-counter pain relievers such as acetaminophen or ibuprofen can help relieve pain and reduce inflammation.
  • ➤ Watch for signs of infection: Keep an eye on the abrasion for signs of infection such as redness, swelling, pus, or increasing pain.
  • ➤ Follow up: Depending on the severity of the abrasion, you may need to follow up with a healthcare provider for further evaluation and treatment.

questions.text: You are an intern and want to determine the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient. How much amount of transient loss/insensible loss per day would you account for in your calculations? ( AIIMS Nov 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 500-600 ml

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When calculating the quantity of IV fluids needed for a patient, it is essential to account for approximately 500-600 ml/day of insensible water loss due to evaporation from the respiratory tract and diffusion through the skin.

questions.text: A child was brought to the emergency department with a big lesion on his forearm. As a surgery resident you decide to excise the lesion in the emergency operation theatre. Which of the following investigations will test the entire coagulation pathway? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Thromboelastography

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thromboelastography (TEG) is the most comprehensive test for evaluating the entire coagulation pathway, including coagulation factor activity, platelet function, and fibrinolysis, making it ideal for intraoperative and emergency settings.
  • ➤ Thromboelastography (TEG)
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537061/
  • ➤ Ref: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537061/

questions.text: The graph below shows the relationship between the log(dose) and the response of three drugs, A, B, and C. Which of these drugs has the highest potency? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In a dose-response curve, the drug with the curve furthest to the left is the most potent because it produces the desired effect at the lowest dose. In this case, Drug A is the most potent.

questions.text: A patient presented to the casualty with signs of dehydration due to severe vomiting. The intern gave the patient a parenteral medication, following which the patient developed grimacing and abnormal posturing. What could have been the inciting drug for this reaction? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Metoclopramide

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Metoclopramide, an anti-emetic that blocks D2 receptors and crosses the blood-brain barrier, can cause extrapyramidal side effects such as acute dystonia, drowsiness, abnormal posturing, and Parkinsonism-like symptoms.

questions.text: A 73-year-old individual arrives with painless rectal bleeding. Which of the listed investigations are conducted for this patient? ( INICET MAY 2023) Colonoscopy CECT CEA CA 19-9
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1, 2 and 3

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Given the patient's presenting symptom of painless rectal bleeding:
  • ➤ Colonoscopy is a primary diagnostic tool to visualize and biopsy any potential sources of bleeding. CECT could be useful in determining the extent of a potential tumor or to check for other causes of bleeding. CEA might be used to check for the possibility of colorectal cancer.
  • ➤ Colonoscopy is a primary diagnostic tool to visualize and biopsy any potential sources of bleeding.
  • ➤ CECT could be useful in determining the extent of a potential tumor or to check for other causes of bleeding.
  • ➤ CEA might be used to check for the possibility of colorectal cancer.
  • ➤ Hence, the investigations that would be most appropriate and relevant for this patient would be options 1, 2, and 3 . Therefore, answer choice D) 1, 2, and 3 is correct.
  • ➤ 1, 2, and 3

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it actually contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Misbranded drug

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ A drug labeled inaccurately with respect to its active ingredient quantity is considered a misbranded drug. Ensuring accurate labeling is crucial for regulatory compliance and consumer safety, as it ensures that drugs on the market are labeled truthfully and can be trusted for their intended use.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant woman at 12 weeks of gestation presents to the obstetrics clinic for routine prenatal care. She has a known history of Graves' disease and was started on antithyroid medication before conception. She reports compliance with her medication but is concerned about potential effects on her baby. Physical examination is unremarkable, and her thyroid function tests show slightly elevated free T4 and suppressed TSH. The patient continues her pregnancy without complications until delivery at term. At birth, the newborn is noted to have a congenital scalp defect, characterized as aplasia cutis congenita. Given the history and clinical findings, which antithyroid drug used during pregnancy is most likely responsible for this congenital abnormality?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Carbimazole is an antithyroid drug that is metabolized into Methimazole (MMI) in the body. Both Carbimazole and Methimazole are associated with teratogenic effects, particularly when used during the first trimester of pregnancy, due to their impact on fetal development during organogenesis. These drugs can cause congenital anomalies, including aplasia cutis congenita, a condition characterized by localized absence of skin, commonly on the scalp. To minimize these risks, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is recommended during the first trimester as it has a lower teratogenic profile. After 16 weeks of gestation, the treatment typically switches to Methimazole or Carbimazole because PTU is associated with hepatotoxicity, which is more concerning later in pregnancy. During lactation, Methimazole is preferred, and Radioactive Iodine is avoided, particularly in the early postpartum period, to prevent radiation exposure to the infant.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Propylthiouracil (PTU) PTU is preferred during the first trimester of pregnancy due to its lower risk of teratogenicity compared to Carbimazole and Methimazole. Although it can cause hepatotoxicity, it does not lead to aplasia cutis congenita.
  • • Option A. Propylthiouracil (PTU)
  • • Option C. Lugol's Iodine Lugol's Iodine is sometimes used to reduce thyroid hormone levels rapidly but is not commonly associated with congenital defects like aplasia cutis congenita. Its primary use is in preparation for thyroid surgery or severe hyperthyroidism, and it is not considered a first-line antithyroid drug during pregnancy.
  • • Option C. Lugol's Iodine
  • • Option D. Radioactive Iodine (RAI) Radioactive Iodine is contraindicated during pregnancy due to its destructive effects on fetal thyroid tissue. However, it is not linked to aplasia cutis congenita and is strictly avoided during pregnancy and lactation to prevent harm to the fetus and infant.
  • • Option D. Radioactive Iodine (RAI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Carbimazole and Methimazole are associated with teratogenic effects, especially when used in the first trimester, including the risk of aplasia cutis congenita. To minimize fetal risks, Propylthiouracil (PTU) is preferred during early pregnancy, with a switch to Methimazole or Carbimazole after the first trimester due to PTU’s potential hepatotoxicity. During lactation, Methimazole is preferred, and Radioactive Iodine is strictly avoided to protect the infant from radiation exposure through breast milk

questions.text: Which vaccine is not recommended to be given before splenectomy in a 5-year-old child with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Typhoid vaccine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Typhoid vaccine is often deferred in children with hereditary spherocytosis and hypersplenism before splenectomy due to the risk of transiently reduced platelet count, which can be problematic in the presence of hypersplenism. Other vaccines, such as the pneumococcal, Haemophilus influenzae B, and meningococcal vaccines, may be administered based on routine immunization recommendations and the individual's spleen status.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an off-label use of risperidone? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Bipolar disorder

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Risperidone is FDA-approved for the treatment of bipolar disorder, making it a labeled use. In contrast, the use of risperidone for OCD, dementia, and PTSD are off-label indications.

questions.text: What is the most frequently observed tumor in the retroperitoneal space? (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Liposarcoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant and may be of various origins. Mesodermal tumors are the most common malignant retroperitoneal tumors. The order of frequency for primary retroperitoneal malignancy is liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and malignant nerve sheath tumors. Liposarcoma has three histologic varieties, which are well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid/round cell liposarcoma. Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while well-differentiated liposarcoma is the least malignant.
  • ➤ Retroperitoneal tumors can be benign or malignant and may be of various origins.
  • ➤ Mesodermal tumors are the most common malignant retroperitoneal tumors.
  • ➤ The order of frequency for primary retroperitoneal malignancy is liposarcoma, leiomyosarcoma, rhabdomyosarcoma, fibrosarcoma, and malignant nerve sheath tumors.
  • ➤ Liposarcoma has three histologic varieties, which are well-differentiated and undifferentiated liposarcoma, pleomorphic liposarcoma, and myxoid/round cell liposarcoma.
  • ➤ Among the three subtypes, pleomorphic liposarcoma is the most malignant and often metastasizes, while well-differentiated liposarcoma is the least malignant.

questions.text: The rise in blood pressure that occurs at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is a result of? (INICET MAY 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to left ventricular pressure

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

questions.correct_answer: B. Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The rise in blood pressure at the onset of the Valsalva maneuver is primarily due to the increase in intrathoracic pressure adding to aortic pressure, along with increased sympathetic activity.

questions.text: Which of the following molecules are involved in helping the leukocytes to roll over the endothelial cells in the vessels? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) E-selectin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ E-selectin is critical for the rolling of leukocytes along the endothelial cells during the early stages of the inflammatory response.

questions.text: A 21-year-old man with a recent diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) has been undergoing treatment with arsenic trioxide and all-trans retinoic acid. After one week of therapy, he presents to the emergency department with high fever, shortness of breath, and new bilateral infiltrates on his chest X-ray. His physical examination reveals tachypnea and mild hypoxia. What is the next best step in management?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This patient’s presentation is highly suggestive of differentiation syndrome, a serious complication associated with the treatment of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML) with arsenic trioxide and all-trans retinoic acid. Differentiation syndrome is characterized by fever, respiratory distress, pulmonary infiltrates, and pleural effusions that develop during the initial weeks of therapy. The first-line treatment is high-dose corticosteroids, specifically dexamethasone, which helps reduce inflammation and prevent progression of the syndrome. Prompt recognition and early administration of dexamethasone can significantly improve outcomes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B) Ciprofloxacin: While ciprofloxacin is an antibiotic used for bacterial infections, it is not effective in treating differentiation syndrome. This syndrome is inflammatory rather than infectious, so antibiotics are not beneficial unless a secondary bacterial infection is confirmed.
  • • Option B) Ciprofloxacin:
  • • Option C) Amphotericin B: Amphotericin B is an antifungal medication typically used for invasive fungal infections. Although immunocompromised patients like those with leukemia may be at risk for fungal infections, the clinical features of differentiation syndrome do not align with those of a fungal etiology.
  • • Option C) Amphotericin B:
  • • Option D) Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG): IVIG is used in various conditions, including autoimmune disorders and certain immunodeficiencies. However, it has no role in managing differentiation syndrome, which primarily requires anti-inflammatory therapy rather than immune modulation.
  • • Option D) Intravenous Immunoglobulin (IVIG):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Differentiation syndrome is a potentially life-threatening complication of acute promyelocytic leukemia treatment with arsenic trioxide and all-trans retinoic acid. It presents with fever, respiratory distress, and pulmonary infiltrates, and is effectively treated with high-dose corticosteroids like dexamethasone. Prompt recognition and initiation of corticosteroids are essential for reducing morbidity and preventing progression.

questions.text: Which of the following is a good prognostic factor for breast cancer patients? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) ER+

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ER-positive status in breast cancer is a good prognostic factor because it indicates a slower-growing tumor that is likely to respond well to hormone therapy.

questions.text: Cholecysto-vena caval line passes through? (NEET PG 2019)

options.label: B
options.text: Porta hepatis and inferior vena cava

options.label: D
options.text: Right and left lobe of liver

questions.correct_answer: A. Gallbladder and inferior vena cava
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Gallbladder and inferior vena cava

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cholecysto-vena caval line is an imaginary line drawn from the fundus of the gallbladder to the point where the inferior vena cava (IVC) pierces the diaphragm. It roughly demarcates the boundary between the right and left lobes of the liver, especially when viewed from behind (posterior view).

questions.text: Which of the following is more appropriate for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genome?(INICET NOV 2021)

options.label: B
options.text: Conventional PCR with Restriction Fragment Length pair technique

options.label: D
options.text: RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR

questions.correct_answer: D. RT-PCR followed by Real time PCR
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) RTPCR followed by Real time PCR

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Real-time PCR is the most appropriate technique for quantitative analysis of viral RNA genomes, allowing real-time monitoring and quantification of viral RNA load.

questions.text: A 58-year-old woman was undergoing cholecystectomy. During the procedure, the resident accidentally advanced the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen causing injury. Which of the following structures is likely to be injured?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Caudate lobe of liver

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The caudate lobe is a small, distinct lobe of the liver that lies posterior to the porta hepatis and forms the posterior border of the lesser omentum. Importantly, it forms the superior border of the epiploic foramen. Thus, during cholecystectomy, an injury advancing the scissors along the superior border of the epiploic foramen could damage the caudate lobe.
  • • superior border
  • • Epiploic foramen is a vertical slit of about 3 cm behind the free right border of the lesser omentum. It connects the lesser sac to the greater sac.
  • • Clinical note: Pringle maneuver (as shown below) is a technique where the free margin of the lesser omentum is compressed to obtain rapid control of bleeding from the hepatic artery and portal vein in liver trauma and surgery.
  • • Clinical note:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Right lobe of liver : The right lobe of the liver is a major lobe, and it constitutes the majority of the liver's mass. It does not directly border the epiploic foramen. The anterior surface of the right lobe faces the anterior abdominal wall, and the posterior surface is related to the diaphragm and right kidney.
  • • Option A.
  • • Right lobe of liver
  • • Option B . Quadrate lobe of liver : The quadrate lobe is a smaller lobe situated on the visceral surface of the liver. It is bounded by the gallbladder on the right and the round ligament of the liver on the left. It is separated from the left lobe by the fissure for the ligamentum teres. While it's close to the region, the quadrate lobe does not form the superior border of the epiploic foramen.
  • • Option B
  • • Quadrate lobe of liver
  • • Option D . Fundus of gallbladder : The fundus is the most distal part of the gallbladder and it usually projects beyond the inferior border of the liver, contacting the anterior abdominal wall. It is not directly related to the epiploic foramen.
  • • Option D
  • • Fundus of gallbladder
